questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of the secretory or exocytotic pathway of protein sorting?

options.label: A
options.text: Endoplasmic Reticulum→ Golgi Apparatus→ Plasma Membrane→ Release into the external environment

options.label: B
options.text: Golgi Apparatus→ Endoplasmic Reticulum→ Plasma Membrane→ Release into the external environment

options.label: C
options.text: Plasma Membrane→ Endoplasmic Reticulum→ Golgi Apparatus→ Release into the external environment

options.label: D
options.text: Plasma Membrane→ Golgi Apparatus → Endoplasmic Reticulum →Release into the external environment

questions.correct_answer: A. Endoplasmic Reticulum→ Golgi Apparatus→ Plasma Membrane→ Release into the external environment
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoplasmic Reticulum→ Golgi Apparatus→ Plasma Membrane→ Release into the external environment In the secretory or exocytotic pathway, proteins are transported from the Endoplasmic Reticulum → Golgi Apparatus → Plasma Membrane and then released into the external environment . This is done through the formation of secretory vesicles.

Extraedge:

It is important to differentiate secretory vesicles from transport vesicles. Vesicles carrying proteins destined for the Golgi, plasma membrane, and certain other sites, or for secretion are carried in transport vesicles. Vesicles carrying certain proteins destined exclusively for secretion outside the cell (e.g. hormones) are carried in secretory vesicles.

questions.text: In order to keep ion gradients across their membrane, red blood cells need ATP in the absence of which they will enlarge and burst causing hemolytic anemia. The main process by which RBCs generate their energy is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Substrate-level phosphorylation Red blood cells do not contain mitochondria and can only generate energy via anaerobic glycolysis with the production of lactate and production of ATP by substrate-level phosphorylation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option B: TCA cycle The TCA cycle occurs in mitochondria so, cannot occur in RBCs. Options C and D: Oxidative phosphorylation and Electron transfer to oxygen Oxidative phosphorylation is the production of ATP when electrons from the reducing equivalents get transferred through protein complexes to be finally accepted by O 2 and in the process form ATP from ADP. The ETC also occurs within the mitochondria.

questions.text: Lipids present in Inner Mitochondrial Membrane (IMM) assist in the proper activity of proteins and enzyme complexes of ETC. A major lipid present in IMM is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cardiolipin Cardiolipin is a phospholipid that is present in the inner mitochondrial membrane It is found only in mitochondria It has a complex structure made up of glycerol attached to two Phosphatidic acids. Properties and Function It has a role in apoptosis signaling It acts as an anticoagulant It increases the efficiency of oxidative phosphorylation by acting as a proton trap. Barth Syndrome – a rare X-linked disorder, that occurs due to defects in cardiolipin remodeling. Patients have muscle weakness, neutropenia, and cardiomyopathy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. Inositol It is a cyclic sugar alcohol and acts as a mediator for the action of various hormones, neurotransmitters, and growth factors. It also serves as a precursor for the synthesis of structural lipids phosphatidylinositol (PI) and phosphatidylinositol phosphate (PIP) lipids. Option: B. Plasmalogen These are phosphoglycerides with an unsaturated fatty alcohol rather than fatty acid attached at the C1 position of glycerol by an ether bond. Ethanolamine is the widely present head group at the C3 position. Option: D. Lecithin Lecithin (phosphatidylcholine) is one of the major membrane glycerophospholipids. dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine has a major role as a lung surfactant and its deficiency leads to respiratory distress syndrome in newborns.

questions.text: A variety of dietary plans and exercise regimen are recommended and used by dietitians and trainers for weight management. One of them among is Atkins diet which is a:
questions.correct_answer: D. Low calorie, low carbohydrate diet
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Low calorie, low carbohydrate diet Atkin’s diet is a weight-loss diet that is low in calorie and also low in carbohydrates. It was originally promoted by the physician Dr. Robert C. Atkins. For weight reduction, the amount of carbohydrates taken in the diet should be less as carbohydrate gets converted to fats in the body, which is called endogenous fat and it gets transported in the form of VLDL

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options Option: A. Low-calorie diet Low-calorie diet mainly comprises non-digestible carbohydrates such as fiber and salads. They can help in weight loss but can also deprive the body of essential nutrients. Option: B. Low carbohydrate diet Low carbohydrate but high protein-rich diets are also recommended for weight loss as proteins have high SDA and excess protein are not stored as fats. Option: C. Low- fat diet Diets lower in fats and carbohydrates and rich in protein are the most popular and most recommended diets specially for people with problems such as high cholesterol and triglycerides, heart problems, and damaged arteries. However, high-fat diets aka keto diets are also becoming popular for weight loss for healthy individuals.

questions.text: High-energy phosphate compound is/are: ATP Creatine phosphate Glucose- 1- phosphate Glycerol -3-phosphate ADP Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, and 5 are correct Statement 1 and 5: ATP and ADP The high-energy compounds are those which release standard free energy on their hydrolysis which is generally coupled for the formation of ATP or other precursors used in synthesis or catabolic reactions. Energy is released because products formed after hydrolysis are in more stable forms than the original compound. The hydrolysis of anhydride P-O bonds are exergonic and releases energy with large negative ΔG o . Statement: 2 : Creatine Phosphate Creatine phosphate aka phosphocreatine is a phosphorylated creatine molecule. It serves as a rapidly mobilizable source of energy in skeletal muscle, myocardium, and the brain. It helps in the formation of ATP from ADP by coupling its hydrolysis to creatine and phosphate.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options Statement 3: Glucose-1-Phosphate Glucose-1-Phosphate is a product of the hydrolysis of glycogen by glycogen phosphorylase and enters glycolysis by converting to glucose-6-P by phosphoglucomutase. It also acts as a precursor for glycogenesis by converting to UDP-Glucose. Statement 4: Glycerol-3-Phosphate Glycerol 3-P is an intermediate for the glycerol phosphate shuttle. It gets formed from DHAP in the cytoplasm, crosses into mitochondria, and forms DHAP also forming FADH 2 which enters ETC. It is also a precursor for the synthesis of TG in the liver and adipose tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about lysosomal storage disorders are true/false? A.Increased number and size of lysosomes B.Accumulation of the polyubiquitinated proteins C.No neurological defect D.Apoptosis Defect E.Inborn diseases Select the correct answer from the given below code:

options.label: A
options.text: A- T, B- T, C- F, D- T, E- T

options.label: B
options.text: A-F, B- F, C- F, D- T, E- T

options.label: C
options.text: A-T, B- F, C- F, D- F, E- T

options.label: D
options.text: A-F, B- T, C- T, D- T, E- T

questions.correct_answer: A. A- T, B- T, C- F, D- T, E- T
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A- T, B- T, C- F, D- T, E- T Statement A: Increased number and size of lysosomes Lysosomal storage disorders are inborn diseases due to the lack or inactivity of lysosomal hydrolases, transporters, or integral membrane proteins. In order to make up for the loss of activity there is induction of lysosome biogenesis (increase in lysosome number). Substrate accumulation in lysosomes increases the size of lysosomes

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Statement B: Accumulation of the polyubiquitinated proteins There are large vacuoles and ubiquitinated aggregates as a result of the accumulation of substrates of defective enzymes. Statement C: No neurological defect Signs and symptoms of LSDs: developmental delay and movement disorders Seizures and dementia Deafness and blindness Enlarged livers or spleens Pulmonary and cardiac problems Abnormal bone growth Statement E: Lysosomal enzymes such as some proteases are necessary for apoptosis progression and in LSD the apoptosis is negatively affected.

questions.text: Match the organelle with its biochemical marker: Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1-e, 2-c, 3-f, 4-a Statement: A. Biochemical marker for Lysosomes : Acid Phosphatase Acid Phosphatase catalyzes the hydrolysis of phosphate from a variety of phosphate esters Tissue/cell localization: Prostate, erythrocytes Diagnostic enzyme for metastatic prostatic carcinoma

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Statement: B. Biochemical marker for Peroxisomes : Catalase Catalase Is a peroxidase present in blood and tissues A heme-containing enzyme Converts harmful H 2 O 2 into H 2 O and O 2 Statement: C. Biochemical marker for Endoplasmic Reticulum : Glucose-6-Phosphatase Glucose-6-Phosphatase Exclusively present in liver ER and absent from muscles Last enzyme of gluconeogenesis to release glucose from Glucose 6-Phosphate Statement: D. Biochemical marker for Ribosomes : rRNA rRNA: A major component of ribosomes Variable in size Synthesized in nucleolus 23S rRNA of prokaryotes and 28S rRNA of eukaryotes acts as Ribozyme

questions.text: Coenzymes and electron carriers play a vital role in cellular metabolism by providing the necessary redox environment. Which among the following is mainly required for Anabolic reactions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NADP All of these are products of dehydrogenase reaction shown as NADPH is used for Reductive biosynthesis, i.e. mainly anabolic reactions. Reductase enzyme is required for at least one or more steps of anabolic reaction such as: Here the best answer is NADP (If NADPH is given, mark that)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. NAD NAD + is the major coenzyme for enzymes catalyzing oxidation reaction of fuel molecules and accepts two-electron and one H + in the form of H - ion to get reduced to NADH + H + Reduced form NADH uses complex I, III, and IV of ETC to give 2.5 ATP per molecule Option: C and D. FAD and FADP FAD is the coenzyme for enzymes catalyzing oxidation reaction of fuel molecules and can accept two electrons and two H + to form FADH 2 . Reduced form FADH 2 uses complex I, III, and IV of ETC to give 1.5 ATP per molecule The phosphate form of FAD i.e. FADP is not present naturally in the organisms.

questions.text: Mitochondria are involved in all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cholesterol synthesis Cholesterol synthesis I t is an anabolic pathway and anabolic pathways generally occur in the cytoplasm. Most of the steps of cholesterol synthesis also occur in cytoplasm however last few steps (after squalene synthesis) occur in ER. Insulin activates this pathway by promoting dephosphorylation of RLE HMG CoA reductase.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. ATP production ATP is produced by two processes: Substrate level phosphorylation: this can occur in the cytoplasm (glycolysis) and gives a minor amount of ATP. Oxidative Phosphorylation: This occur exclusively in mitochondria and provides the majority of cellular ATP. So, ATP production can be easily taken to occur in mitochondria. Option: B. Apoptosis Apoptosis is also programmed cell death. It is a cellular-level process and involves a lot of processes occurring in various compartments of the cell including mitochondria Option: C. TCA TCA is an amphibolic and a vital pathway All the enzymes of the TCA cycle are present in mitochondria. It provides precursors for the synthesis of various biomolecules and also intermediates of various catabolic pathways that enter into TCA for further oxidation.

questions.text: Proteins are produced by the process of translation, is directed by messenger RNA (mRNA). Which of the following cellular component is directly involved in the process of protein synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ribosomes The main process of protein synthesis occurs in ribosomes. Ribosomes are made of two subunits that come together at the start of translation. mRNA gets bound by ribosomal protein synthetic machinery to give rise to native polypeptides.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. Smooth endoplasmic reticulum These are ER that do not contain ribosomes on their surface. So, they are not involved in protein synthesis. Their function includes: Detoxification of drugs Ca +2 sequestration & release Option: B. Rough endoplasmic reticulum Rough ER is the ER to which ribosomes are attached. Native polypeptide formed on these ribosomes passes into RER for further processing such as folding and post-translational Their function includes: Synthesis of proteins that are exported outside the cell e.g. insulin Synthesis of lipid required for outer membrane of nucleus, lysosomes Option D: Mitochondria Mitochondria synthesizes its own protein such as those involved in ETC with the help of its own protein synthetic machinery which include its own ribosomes and mRNA. So, it can be said that mitochondria are not directly involved in protein synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the source of cytosolic NADPH?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ATP citrate lyase It is an enzyme involved in citrate shuttle that is used to supply substrates for fatty acid synthesis. It converts citrate to oxaloacetate and acetyl CoA using CoA and ATP (Generally, Lyases do not use ATP) It is an anabolic enzyme but active in the phosphorylated state as an exception. Generally, anabolic enzymes are active in a dephosphorylated state. Sources of cytosolic NADPH

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. Isocitrate dehydrogenase 3 isoenzymes One, which uses (NAD+) in Mitochondria The other two use NADP + in Mitochondria and cytosol Option: C. Malic enzyme another enzyme of citrate shuttle converts malate to pyruvate with the generation of NADPH and CO 2 NADPH produced is mainly utilized for the fatty acid synthesis Option: D. G6PD (Glucose 6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase) First and RLE of HMP pathway (alternative pathway to glycolysis and TCA cycle for the oxidation of glucose) Synthesizes NADPH by oxidation of glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate Genetic deficiency of this enzyme result in hemolysis

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a major function of the endoplasmic reticulum?

options.label: C
options.text: Providing enzymes that control glycogen breakdown

options.label: D
options.text: Secretion of proteins synthesized in the cell

questions.correct_answer: D. Secretion of proteins synthesized in the cell
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Secretion of proteins synthesized in the cell Though folding and some post-translational modifications of newly synthesized proteins are done in ER, packaging and secretion of proteins is mainly done by the Golgi apparatus . In the secretory or exocytotic pathway, proteins are transported from the Endoplasmic Reticulum → Golgi Apparatus → Plasma Membrane and then released into the external environment. This is done through secretory vesicles.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. The manufacturing of the lipids and fat molecules specially elongation and desaturation of fatty acids take place in the smooth ER. Desaturation occurs in liver ER. Enzymes for desaturation and elongation are present in the ER and they can create double bonds at 4, 5, 6, and 9 positions. Elongation of fatty acid up to 24C in ER is done by fatty acyl elongases. C-22 and C-24 FAs are specially required in the brain for the formation of sphingomyelin Option: B. Proteins are synthesized on the ribosomes which are present on the surface of the ER known as Rough ER (RER). Though ER is not directly involved in protein still they help in proper folding and some post-translational modifications of newly synthesized proteins. Option: C. The liver endoplasmic reticulum has the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase which performs: Last step of glycogen breakdown to release free glucose from glucose 6-phosphate. Last step of gluconeogenesis to release glucose from Glucose 6-Phosphate

questions.text: A child presents with hypotonia and seizures. It was confirmed to be Zellweger syndrome. Which of the following accumulates in the brain?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Long-chain fatty acid Zellweger syndrome It is also called as Cerebro-Hepato-Renal Syndrome. It is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder. Absence of Peroxisomes in almost all tissues, peroxisomes are responsible for the oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA) which contain more than 22 carbons. So, accumulation of VLCFA (C > 22) occurs especially in the brain, as brain sphingomyelins are rich in long-chain fatty acids. Clinical features: Severe neurological symptoms such as Impaired neuronal migration, hypomyelination, hepatomegaly, and renal cysts. Most patients die within 1st year of their life.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A and B. Glucose and Lactic acid Glucose and lactic acid metabolism occur in the cytoplasm and do not involve peroxisomes. Hence, they will be metabolized normally. Option: D. TG Here TG refers to stored adipose tissue TG. Peroxisomes are involved in α-oxidation for branched-chain amino acid and oxidation of VLCFA. As adipose tissue TG generally does not contain either of these two types of FA, so the metabolism of TG will not be affected.

questions.text: Intercellular communication in Eukaryotes is mediated by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Exosomes Exosomes are extracellular vesicles that contain constituents (protein, DNA, RNA) of the cells that secrete them. They are taken up by distant cells which can affect cell function and behavior. So, they are involved in intercellular communication through the exchange of material and information between cells.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect Options:- Option: A. Peroxisomes The function of peroxisomes include: Free radical destruction e.g. peroxisomal enzymes catalase & peroxidase destroy H 2 O 2 Oxidation of long-chain fatty acid Synthesis of Plasmalogen which is the main phospholipid in the myelin sheath of the brain Option: B. Lysosomes Lysosomes are digestive organelles that contain hydrolases for digestion and the breakdown of macromolecules of hydrolases causes Lysosomal storage disease of various macromolecules such as GAGs and lipids. Option: D. Microsomes These are intercellular vesicles formed by disruption of RER during cell fractionation. Contain membrane proteins and enzymes and used for the study of structure and function in vitro.

questions.text: Which of the following food is having a high thermic effect?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Proteins Specific dynamic action (SDA), also known as the thermic effect of food (TEF) is the amount of energy expenditure above the basal metabolic rate due to the cost of processing food for use and storage. As it refers to the heat produced after eating it is known as dietary-induced thermogenesis (DIT) For example, dietary fat is very easy to process and has very little thermic effect, while protein is hard to process and has a much larger thermic effect. High SDA of proteins is generally attributed to meeting the energy requirements for oxidative deamination, synthesis of urea, and biosynthesis of proteins. table,tr,th,td {border:1px solid black;} Food component TEF as % of calorific value of food Protein 20-30 Fats 11-13 Carbohydrate 5 Mixed Diet 10
